title: E field of distribution - 60 and 120 degree arcs

content.question: Two charge distributions, Distribution <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Distribution <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are in the shape of circular arcs of the same radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, as shown in the figure, with centers at points <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Distribution <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> subtends an arc of <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math> degrees, and Distribution <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> subtends an arc of <math alttext="120" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>120</mn></math> degrees. Both distributions have the same uniform linear charge density <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Î»</mi></math>. Which of the following correctly relates the electric field magnitudes <math alttext="E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> at points <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="P sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively?

choices.label: <math alttext="E sub 1 equals E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="E sub 1 is less than E sub 2, which is less than 2 E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub 2 equals 2 E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub 2 is greater than 2 E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="E sub 1 is less than E sub 2, which is less than 2 E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
